title: Lumalabs image prompt bar
description:
I like their treatment of the digital materiality of the images. Tossing them above the bar with a slight tilt makes it feel lighter, less formal, less at stake and benefits the feeling of remixing something

Also the way they introduce the video descriptions of pan actions after a short delay. Enough time that a familiar user won't see the tutorial, but someone who is hovering over it confused will almost immediately see it.

title: The Design of Everyday Things
description: Good design requires good communication, especially from machine to person, indicating what actions are possible, what is happening, and what is about to happen

title: The communal science lab
description:
The greatest leaps in the progress of civilization have come from new forms for seeing and discussing ideas — written language, mathematical notation, interactive computing — which we might broadly call "user interfaces".

An interface gives physical form to invisible concepts, and in science, invisible and intangible concepts abound.

title: Maeda Laws of Simplicity
description:
Thought provoking, provides directions for improving designs, some overlap with Dieter Rams

Generally, am curious to find more "rules" like this to use simply as prompts that might suggest interesting design/research directions.

title: Dieter Rams 10 Principles
description: Sitting with these. What still feels relevant to interaction design? What principles should be added? Perhaps Maeda's Laws of Simplicity?

title: OP-1 Teenage Engineering
description:
Both functional and beautiful interface design. See Tombola for one of my favorites.

Inspiring to see how expressive they can make a limited set of physical controls. Reminds me of Dieter Rams' principle, "Good design is as little design as possible".

title: Studio Moniker + Coinbase brand identity
description: I like the brightness and boldness of the typography, color and geometries. The interfaces give everything a slightly futuristic energy + the digital billboard type transitions

title: Push pop press - interactive book
description: Big picture + details on demand, persistent digital materiality, interactive images + figures that are slightly off the page to signifier interactivity, information communicated through interaction allowing for interactive analysis

title: Active video player
description: Using multiple representations to give context to the video narrative. All of them are synchronized, and help answer questions + build a better model of the narrative. A kind of peripheral vision.

title: Hyperbind
description:
"As you scroll through the webpage in the left pane, each of its links appears in the right pane."

I like the idea of reducing the friction to view referenced materials while avoiding the overwhelm of having 100s of links open as tabs. "scrolling and opening links in a single gesture"

title: Visual Program Behavior
description: The realization that such a simple rule was behind what I would have assumed was quite complex. Very promising to walk through a complex process like this and grasp how it works almost immediately.
